newsitem.title: USA: D'Amato says concerned about new OCC bank rule.
newsitem.headline: D'Amato says concerned about new OCC bank rule.

text.p: Senate Banking Committee Chairman Alfonse D'Amato said he was "deeply troubled and concerned" over a new bank regulation finalized Wednesday by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.
The New York Republican issued a statement saying the rule would allow certain banks to expand into securities and insurance underwriting, data processing and real estate sales.
The rule "may subject federally insured banks to excessive risks and expose the bank insurance funds, and therefore taxpayers, to unnecessary liability," he said in a statement.
House Banking Committee Chairman James Leach, R-Iowa, in a statement said elements of the new OCC regulations were a step toward "common-sense bank moderinization."

But he added, "it is conjectural whether the courts will pass muster on such sweeping regulatory discretion or whether the Comptroller's actions will have the effect of precipitating or retarding a more comprehensive legislative approach."
The American Council of Life Insurance said it would "mount a major effort" to block the OCC action. The American Bankers Association's securities association praised the rule.
